chapter: Gastrointestinal Tract-Basics Of Git And Esophagus

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the layers of the digestive tract is incorrect?

options.A: The mucosa is the first layer of the digestive tract.
options.B: The submucosa is absent in the gallbladder.
options.C: The muscularis propria is present throughout the GIT.
options.D: The esophagus lacks the submucosal layer.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer:D) The esophagus lacks the submucosal layer Explanation: “ The oesophagus lacks the submucosa layer” is incorrect as it contains submucosa but lacks serosa. The GIT is histologically made up of 4 layers. Layer Description Mucosa Innermost Layer (Option A) Mucous Membrane Lamina Propria Muscularis Mucosa Lining Epithelium (Varies by Region) Esophagus: Nonkeratinized Squamous Epithelium Stomach: Simple Columnar Epithelium Intestine: Simple Columnar Epithelium with Brush Border Anal Canal: Columnar Epithelium above Pectinate Line Stratified Squamous Epithelium below Pectinate Line Submucosa Contains: Nerves (Meissner's Plexus) Absent in Gallbladder (Mucosa directly supported by Connective Tissue) (Option B) Muscularis Propria Responsible for Peristaltic Movements (Propels Food from Esophagus to Anal Canal) Contains Myenteric Nerve Plexus Present throughout the GI tract (Option C) Serosa Outer Protective Sheath (Most of Intestine) It is the visceral peritoneum, as peritoneum is absent in the thoracic cavity, hence the esophagus is covered by adventitia. (Option D)

questions.question: A 58-year-old male presents with chronic heartburn and regurgitation. Upper endoscopy reveals the presence of Barrett's esophagus. What is the primary cellular change seen in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer:A) Metaplasia of squamous epithelium Explanation : The primary cellular change seen in Barrett's oesophagus is metaplasia of squamous epithelium into intestinal/columnar epithelium. Dysplasia of squamous epithelium(Option B). Dysplasia is a premalignant change that refers to disordered cell growth with pleomorphism, abnormal architecture and a loss of orderly differentiation. It is seen in long-standing and untreated cases of Barrett's oesophagus. Hyperplasia and hypertrophy(Options C & D) refer to an increase in the number and size of cells, respectively. Barrett's refers to a change in cell type, not number or size.

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents with chronic heartburn for two years. An endoscopy is performed, and the biopsy of the esophageal specimen stained with special stain is shown below. Which of the following conditions is the patient at an increased risk of?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer:B) Adenocarcinoma Explanation: The above scenario and an image showing goblet cells within the columnar epithelium suggest Barret’s esophagus, which puts the patient at an increased risk of adenocarcinoma of the esophagus. Esophageal disease progression A: Normal esophagus; B: Esophagitis; C: BE with goblet cells; D: Dysplasia; E: EAC. EAC: Esophageal adenocarcinoma; BE: Barrett's esophagus. Barrett's esophagus is diagnosed based on endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. It is seen as red, velvety mucosa extending upward from the gastroesophageal junction. questions.question: A woman presented with dysphagia to solids for a month. On examination, there are multiple lesions on the lips. An endoscopy reveals obstructive lesions in the upper oesophagus. Which of the following additional findings can be seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Iron deficiency anemia Explanation: This patient's condition is most likely suggestive of Plummer-Vinson syndrome, which is associated with iron deficiency anemia. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome (Paterson-Kelly Syndrome, Sideropenic Dysphagia) Characterized by a triad of: Iron-deficiency anemia Upper esophageal webs Post- Cricoid Dysphagia Common in middle-aged women Increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma (pharynx and proximal esophagus) Other Findings Glossitis Angular cheilitis Koilonychia Post cricoid Dysphagia Caused by esophageal webs/rings in the upper esophagus This leads to swallowing difficulties, especially with solid foods Worsens over time Aetiology and Treatment Iron deficiency is the main cause Treatable with iron supplementation Other options: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome ( Option A) features GI polyps and mucocutaneous lesions with dark blue to dark brown melanotic macules around the mouth. It is not typically associated with dysphagia and esophageal webs. Degeneration of nitric oxide –producing neurons ( Option B) is a feature of achalasia. It is characterized by incomplete lower esophageal sphincter relaxation, increased sphincter tone, and aperistalsis of the esophagus. Apple core appearance(Option D) on imaging is seen in oesophageal carcinoma due to irregular narrowing of the esophagus with mucosal irregularity. It initially presents with dysphagia to solids. However, there are typically no oral lesions in oesophageal cancer.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of severe odynophagia, retrosternal chest pain, and difficulty in swallowing solids and liquids for the past week. He has a history of untreated HIV infection with a CD4 count of 80 cells/mm³. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Candida esophagitis Explanation The clinical scenario and endoscopy showing curd-like plaques suggest candida oesophagitis. Infective Esophagitis: Affects immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV/AIDS, cancer patients, long-term corticosteroid therapy) Candida Esophagitis Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Esophagitis (Option A) Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Esophagitis (Option B) Endoscopic finding Adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes over erythematous mucosa Punched-out ulcers Shallow, linear, or longitudinal ulcerations Histopathology Fungal Hyphae And Inflammatory Cells Multinucleated Giant Cells, Ground-Glass Nuclei, Eosinophilic Inclusions At Ulcer Margin Owl-Eye Appearance, Eosinophilic Intranuclear, And Basophilic Intracytoplasmic Inclusions Eosinophilic esophagitis(Option C) It presents with dysphagia to solid foods, chest pain, and gastric regurgitation. It is commonly seen in patients with a history of atopy and not immunodeficiency. HPE: A marked infiltrate of intraepithelial eosinophils.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the condition shown in the endoscopic image below?

options.C: Interleukin 5 has a major role in pathogenesis.
options.D: Diagnosed by observing at least ten lymphocytes/HPF.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Interleukin 5 has a major role in pathogenesis. Explanation: The given image suggests eosinophilic esophagitis, where Interleukin 5 has a major role in pathogenesis. Eosinophilic Esophagitis: Triggered by allergic reactions to food or environmental allergens (Option A) Associated with atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, asthma, and peripheral eosinophilia Pathophysiology Interleukin 5 (IL-5) key cytokine for eosinophil maturation and activation Clinical Manifestations Dysphagia Epigastric pain Dyspepsia Chest pain Food impaction Diagnostic Criteria Eosinophils ≥ 15 per high power field (HPF) on HPE (Option D) Endoscopic Findings: Stacked circular rings ("feline esophagus") ( Option C) Strictures Linear furrows Characteristic rat tail appearance (Option B)- The characteristic appearance seen in eosinophilic esophagitis on endoscopy is not a "rat tail" (Rat tail appearance is seen in radiography of cancer esophagus) but rather "feline esophagus." This refers to the presence of stacked circular rings, which resemble the striped tail of a cat.

questions.question: Identify the correct statement/s regarding carcinoma of the oesophagus SCC is more common in the lower two-thirds of the oesophagus Smoking increases the risk of both SCC and adenocarcinoma H. pylori is associated with a decreased risk of oesophageal adenocarcinoma Adenocarcinoma is the overall most common type SCC is linked to fermented milk- mursik, which contains acetaldehyde
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 2, 3, 5 Explanation : Characteristic Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) Adenocarcinoma of Esophagus Predominant location Middle two-thirds of the oesophagus (Statement 1 ruled out) The lower third of the oesophagus, near GE junction Epidemiology Overall, the more common type (Statement 4 ruled out) Increasing due to an increase in GERD Risk Factors Smoking, Alcohol HPV infection Caustic esophageal injury, Achalasia Tylosis Plummer-Vinson syndrome Diets deficient in fruits or vegetables Frequent consumption of very Hot beverages.
